original: Milindapañha🔽Opammakathāpañha🔽Upacikāvagga
analyzed: milindapañha  opamma kathā pañha  upacikā vagga
translated: The Questions of King Milinda🔽The Questions of the Wanderer Sakuludāyī🔽The Chapter about the Spider

original: 10. Hatthiṅgapañha
analyzed: hatthiṅga pañha
translated: The Questions about the Elephant’s Six Limbs

original: “Bhante nāgasena, ‘hatthissa pañca aṅgāni gahetabbānī’ti yaṁ vadesi, katamāni tāni pañca aṅgāni gahetabbānī”ti?
analyzed: bhante nāgasena hatthissa pañca aṅgāni gahetabbāni iti yam vadesi katamāni tāni pañca aṅgāni gahetabbāni iti
translated: “Revered Nāgasena, when you say that five limbs of the elephant should be adopted, which are these five limbs that should be adopted?”

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, hatthī nāma caranto yeva pathaviṁ dāleti;
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja hatthī nāma carantaḥ yā iva pathavim dāla iti
translated: “As, sire, an elephant, while walking, tears up the earth,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena kāyaṁ sammasamāneneva sabbe kilesā dāletabbā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena kāyam sammasamānena iva sabbe kilesā dāletabbā
translated: even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training, while examining the body, should tear up all the defilements.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, hatthissa paṭhamaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja hatthissa paṭhamam aṅgam
translated: This, sire, is the first limb of the elephant that should be adopted.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, hatthī sabbakāyeneva apaloketi, ujukaṁyeva pekkhati, na disāvidisā viloketi;
analyzed: puna capara mahā rāja hatthī sabba kāyena iva apaloketi ujukayā iva pekkhati na disā vidisā viloketi
translated: “And again, sire, an elephant looks straight ahead, he looks evenly, he does not look to the right and left;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena sabbakāyena apalokinā bhavitabbaṁ, na disāvidisā viloketabbā, na uddhaṁ ulloketabbaṁ, na adho oloketabbaṁ, yugamattapekkhinā bhavitabbaṁ.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena sabba kāyena apalokinā bhavitabba na disā avidisā viloketabbā na uddham ulloketabba na adhas oloketabba yuga matta pekkhinā bhavitabba
translated: even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training should look straight ahead with the whole body, he should not look to the right and left, he should not look up, he should not look down, he should look a plough-yoke’s length before him.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, hatthissa dutiyaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja hatthissa dutiyam aṅgam
translated: This, sire, is the second quality of the elephant that must be adopted.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, hatthī anibaddhasayano gocarāyamanugantvā na tameva desaṁ vāsatthamupagacchati, na dhuvappatiṭṭhālayo;
analyzed: puna capara mahā rāja hatthī a nibaddha sayanaḥ gocarāyam anugantvā na tam eva desam vāsattham upagacchati na dhuva patiṭṭhā ālayaḥ
translated: “And again, sire, the elephant, when it goes out to feed, is not tied up, it does not go to the same place to live at night, it is not fixed in its abode.

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena anibaddhasayanena bhavitabbaṁ, nirālayena
analyzed: evam eva khalu mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena a nibaddha sayanena nirālayena
translated: Even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training should not be tied up, he should be without an abode,

original: piṇḍāya gantabbaṁ, yadi passati vipassako manuññaṁ patirūpaṁ ruciradese bhavaṁ maṇḍapaṁ
analyzed: yadi passati vipassakaḥ manuññam pati rūpam rucira dese bhavam maṇḍapa
translated: he should go out for alms, and if he who has insight sees a pleasant, suitable, delightful place, a pavilion,

original: vā rukkhamūlaṁ vā guhaṁ vā pabbhāraṁ vā, tattheva vāsamupagantabbaṁ, dhuvappatiṭṭhālayo na kātabbo.
analyzed: vā rukkha mūlam vā guham vā pabbhāram vā tattha iva vāsam upagantabba dhuva ppatiṭṭhā ālayaḥ na kātabbaḥ
translated: the foot of a tree, a cave, a mountain cleft, he should go and live there, he should not be fixed in his abode.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, hatthissa tatiyaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja hatthissa tatiyam aṅgam gahetabba
translated: This, sire, is the third quality of the elephant that must be adopted.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, hatthī udakaṁ ogāhitvā sucivimalasītalasalilaparipuṇṇaṁ kumuduppalapadumapuṇḍarīkasañchannaṁ mahatimahantaṁ padumasaraṁ ogāhitvā kīḷati gajavarakīḷaṁ;
analyzed: puna capara mahā rāja hatthī udakam ogāhitvā suci vimala sītala salila paripuṇṇam kumuda uppala paduma puṇḍarīka sañchannam mahati mahantam paduma saram ogāhitvā kīḷati gaja vara kīḍa
translated: “And again, sire, the elephant, having gone down into the water, having entered a great lotus-pool filled with pure, clear, cool water, covered with lotuses, lilies and white lotuses, plays the play of the best of elephants;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena sucivimalavippasannamanāviladhammavaravāripuṇṇaṁ
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena suci vimala vippasannam anāvila dhamma vara vāri puṇṇa
translated: Even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training, having entered the lotus-pond of the four foundations of mindfulness, which is filled with the pure, stainless, clear, untroubled water of the Dhamma,

original: vimuttikusumasañchannaṁ mahāsatipaṭṭhānapokkharaṇiṁ ogāhitvā ñāṇena saṅkhārā odhunitabbā
analyzed: vimutti kusuma sañchannam mahā sati paṭṭhāna pokkharaṇim ogāhitvā ñāṇena saṅkhārāḥ odhunitabbā
translated: and which is covered with the flowers of the various kinds of deliverance, should with knowledge shake off and shake down the formations.

original: vidhunitabbā, yogāvacarakīḷā kīḷitabbā.
analyzed: vidhunitabbā yogāvacara kīḷā kīḷitabbā
translated: He should play the game of the one who is devoted to mental training.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, hatthissa catutthaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja hatthissa catuttham aṅgam
translated: This, sire, is the fourth quality of the elephant that must be adopted.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, hatthī sato pādaṁ uddharati, sato pādaṁ nikkhipati;
analyzed: puna capara mahā rāja hatthī sataḥ pādam uddharati sataḥ pādam nikkhipati
translated: “And again, sire, the elephant lifts up his foot mindfully and puts it down mindfully;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena satena sampajānena pādaṁ uddharitabbaṁ,
analyzed: evam eva khalu mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena satena sampajānena pādam
translated: even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training should lift up his foot mindfully and put it down mindfully,

original: satena sampajānena pādaṁ nikkhipitabbaṁ, abhikkamapaṭikkame samiñjanapasāraṇe sabbattha
analyzed: satena sampajānena pādam abhikkama paṭikkame samiñjana pasāraṇe sabbattha
translated: and in going forward and returning, in looking ahead or behind, in bending or stretching (his limbs), in wearing his robes and carrying his outer robe and bowl, in eating, drinking, chewing his food, in evacuating and in coming and going, in standing and sitting, in sleeping and waking, in speaking and in maintaining silence,

original: satena sampajānena bhavitabbaṁ.
analyzed: satena sampajānena
translated: he should be mindful and clearly aware.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, hatthissa pañcamaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja hatthissa pañcamam aṅgam
translated: This, sire, is the fifth quality of the elephant that must be adopted.

original: Bhāsitampetaṁ, mahārāja, bhagavatā devātidevena saṁyuttanikāyavare—🔽‘Kāyena saṁvaro sādhu,
analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā devātidevena sayutta nikāya vare 🔽kāyena savaraḥ sādhu
translated: This, sire, was said by the Blessed One, the god over all gods, in the excellent Saṁyutta Nikāya:

original: sādhu vācāya saṁvaro;
analyzed: sādhu vācāya savaro
translated: Restraint of speech is good,

original: Manasā saṁvaro sādhu,🔽sādhu sabbattha saṁvaro;
analyzed: manasā savaraḥ sādhu  sādhu sabbattha savaraḥ
translated: Restraint of mind is good,🔽Restraint in every way is good;

original: Sabbattha saṁvuto lajjī,
analyzed: sabbattha sa vutaḥ lajjī
translated: The modest one restrained in every way

original: rakkhitoti pavuccatī’”ti.
analyzed: rakkhito ti pavuccati iti
translated: Is said to be protected.”

original: Hatthiṅgapañho dasamo.
analyzed: hatthiṅga pañhaḥ dasamaḥ
translated: The tenth question and answer is finished.

original: Upacikāvaggo catuttho.🔽Tassuddānaṁ
analyzed: upacikā vaggo catuttho  tassa uddāna
translated: The fourth sub-chapter on rats is finished.🔽The summary:🔽Rats, cats,

original: Upacikā biḷāro ca,🔽Undūro vicchikena ca;
analyzed: upacikā biḷāraḥ ca  undūraḥ vicchikena ca
translated: mongeese, and scorpions,

original: Nakulo siṅgālo migo,🔽Gorūpo varāho hatthinā dasāti.
analyzed: nakulaḥ siṅgālaḥ migaḥ 🔽go rūpaḥ varāhaḥ hatthinā dasāti
translated: Weasels, jackals, deer,🔽A monitor lizard, a boar, and an elephant, ten.
